Source.Text: Prompt: “Russia was never really a modern nation (compared with Western Europe) until the beginning of the Cold War.” Assess the validity of this statement.

question.qText: The information about Peter the Great included both elements of continuity and elements of change.

aBtn.aText: True
False

question.qText: Russia would not have been westernized if not for Peter the Great.

aBtn.aText: True
False

question.qText: Peter’s policies served as an agent of change to which of the following areas?

aBtn.aText: The lives of serfs
The culture at the Russian royal court
The borders of Russian territories
Russian language and education
All of the above

question.qText: Which of following supports the thesis that Peter was an agent of change?

aBtn.aText: The passage about Peter the Great
The woodcut about cutting the beard
The map showing the borders of Russia through 1725
A and B only
A, B, and C

question.qText: The reign of Catherine the Great represented

aBtn.aText: <font size='16'>only change because of the introduction of Enlightenment ideas</font>
<font size='16'>only change because she emancipated the serfs</font>
<font size='16'>only continuity because the serfs still mostly lived in rural areas</font>
<font size='16'>both continuity and change because the speaking of French and the introduction of Enlightenment ideas continued the separation between the upper class and the people</font>
<font size='16'>both continuity and change because she kept all of Peter the Great’s reforms, but she was able to reform serfdom</font>

question.qText: Industrialism in Russia is both an agent of continuity and change because it has been a part of the Russian economy since Peter the Great, but expanded more rapidly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

aBtn.aText: True
False

question.qText: The lives of the serfs in Russia

aBtn.aText: changed over time, but culturally featured elements of continuity
exhibited mostly continuity until the Russian Revolution of 1917

question.qText: From Peter, to Catherine, to Nicholas and Alexandra, the Russian upper class

aBtn.aText: had a lot in common with the upper classes of other Western European countries
maintained a backwardness and lack of sophistication that marked them as distinctly “Eastern”

question.qText: By World War II in the Soviet Union,

aBtn.aText: all industries were fully mechanized
industrialization had ground to a halt
industrial growth in some areas had stalled
they were unable to manufacture munitions
had once again enslaved the serfs

question.qText: Which of the following sentences would be correct if used in an essay to address the prompt?

aBtn.aText: <font size='16'>Because Peter and Catherine promoted Western ideas; the Russian upper classes became more modern than serfs and the working classes. </font>
<font size='16'>By the late 1800s, Russian industrial workers were experiencing the same hardships as their western European counterparts.</font>
<font size='16'>If modernism and westernization mean the same; Russia was modern as soon as Peter the Great began forcing serfs to work in factories. </font>
<font size='16'>A and B only</font>
<font size='16'>A, B, and C</font>
